description:
The heated bond between Shana and Yuji is tested as their paranormal adventures continues. The Flame Haze fends off supernatural foes by night. By day, she contends with a classmate who's also after Yuji's heart. Emotions flare as a suspicious transfer student who resembles a recently defeated Denizen clings to Yuji. His training rises in intensity when they catch wind of a revered warrior in search of her lost lover—who will stop at nothing to extract the power keeping Yuji alive!

(Source: FUNimation)
synonyms: ชานะ นักรบเนตรอัคคี ภาคที่ 2

tags.name: Tsundere
tags.description: Prominently features a character who acts cold and hostile in order to mask warmer emotions.

tags.name: School
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a primary or secondary educational institution.

tags.name: Super Power
tags.description: Prominently features characters with special abilities that allow them to do what would normally be physically or logically impossible.

tags.name: Urban Fantasy
tags.description: Set in a world similar to the real world, but with the existence of magic or other supernatural elements.

tags.name: Love Triangle
tags.description: Centered around romantic feelings between more than two people. Includes all love polygons.

tags.name: Heterosexual
tags.description: Prominently features a romance between a man and a woman, not inherently sexual.

tags.name: Primarily Teen Cast
tags.description: Main cast is mostly composed of teen characters.

tags.name: Kuudere
tags.description: Prominently features a character who generally retains a cold, blunt and cynical exterior, but once one gets to know them, they have a very warm and loving interior.

tags.name: Primarily Adult Cast
tags.description: Main cast is mostly composed of characters above a high school age.

node.description:
**Birthplace:** Los Angeles, California
**Spouse:** Rachel Robinson (2019-)

**Introduction:**
Christopher Bevins, alternatively known as Chris Bevins is an American voice actor, ADR director and script/screenwriter. He is more known for his work as an ADR director at FUNimation Productions in Dallas/Fort Worth, Texas.

**Non-anime roles:**
~!- Dhalsim and Soldier A (David) in "Street Fighter V" (VG)
- Dhalsim in "Street Fighter IV" (VG)
- Dhalsim in "Street Fighter X Tekken" (VG)
- Koga, Brycen and Swimmer in "Pokémon Masters" (VG)
- Legault in "Fire Emblem Heroes" (VG)
- Nadai in "Fist of the North Star: Lost Paradise" (VG)
- Shishiwakamaru in "Yu Yu Hakusho: Dark Tournament" (VG)
- Voice in "FUNimation" (logo bumper)
!~
**Non-anime staff credits:**
~!- Script Adaptation for "Sengoku Basara: Samurai Heroes" (VG)!~

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/itoww)

Artist of the Shakugan no Shana and Suzumiya Haruhi novels and the Bee-Be-Beat it! manga series. Employed under the H-game maker UNiSONSHIFT she has worked on 4 H-games: Nanatsuiro Drops, Alice Parade, Peace@Pieces, and Forget Me Not.

[Profile](https://www.imagine-music.co.jp/artist/index/9) | [Twitter](http://twitter.com/kowotani)

After graduating from university, he became a founding member of Yuji Saito's music production company IMAGINE in November 1986. The company has grown to feature musicians like Kohei Tanaka, Shiro Hamaguchi, Hayato Matsuo, and Shinji Miyazaki, who have become well known for cinematic scoring and orchestration through Otani. 

In 1987, he made his debut as an anime composer with the popular manga adaptation City Hunter, which earned him recognition in the industry. He later went on to work on titles such as Spy Games (1988), The Ultimate Teacher (1988), The Yadamura Waltz (1988), and You're Under Arrest (1994). The anime Future GPX Cyber Formula (1991) and Mobile Suit Gundam Wing (1995) and several films in the Gamera series are some of his most well-known works.  In 2001, he created the score to the film Godzilla, Mothra and King Ghidorah: Giant Monsters All-Out Attack. Other notable scores by Otani include Outlaw Star (1998), Gundam Wing: Endless Waltz (1998), Cross Fire (2000), The SoulTaker (2001), Haibane Renmei (2002), Zatch Bell! (2003), Eyeshield 21 (2005), Pumpkin Scissors (2006), Deltora Quest (2007), and Over Drive (2007). He has also been the music director and keyboardist of the band Dreams Come True. He appeared at Eminence Symphony Orchestra's events A Night in Fantasia 2007: Symphonic Games Edition and Unearthing Eden ~The sounds of AINARU~ in 2007.  

Throughout his career, Otani has also composed music for several video games, making his debut with the 1995 shooter game Philosoma. In 2000, he created the soundtrack to the flight simulator Sky Odyssey. He scored Shadow of the Colossus in 2005, his most famous video game work. Otani was responsible for composing the music for Wild Arms: Twilight Venom (2000), an anime adaptation of the Wild Arms video game series; he also arranged compositions of Michiko Naruke's music from the series. He did two more video game to anime adaptations: Night Warriors: Darkstalkers' Revenge (1997) and Popolocrois Monogatari (1998). In 2005, he created the track "Madness" alongside Hiroko Shigezumi for the Square Enix game Heavy Metal Thunder.

[Official Website](https://kotoko.asia) | [Spotify ](https://open.spotify.com/artist/06F1MiFx0dHLHEPQBIrcr9?autoplay=true) | [Blog](http://ameblo.jp/kotoko-kirakira/) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/KOTOKO_Dwarf) | [Warner Home Video](http://whv-amusic.com/kotoko/) | [NBC Universal Japan](http://nbcuni-music.com/kotoko/) | [YouTube ](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCYZ9uuJYYP5PX8YvpIHbEwQ)

KOTOKO is a Japanese J-pop musician, singer and songwriter. She began her singing career as a member of [I've Sound ](https://anilist.co/staff/106951/Ive) in 2000, and was later signed to Rondorobe under Geneon from 2004 to 2010. Kotoko left Geneon in 2010, left I've Sound and signed to Warner Home Video in 2011. She composes and writes lyrics (for herself as well as other singers in I've Sound) for numerous other song collections. She has contributed songs to numerous anime and video games.

[Official Website](https://kotoko.asia) | [Spotify ](https://open.spotify.com/artist/06F1MiFx0dHLHEPQBIrcr9?autoplay=true) | [Blog](http://ameblo.jp/kotoko-kirakira/) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/KOTOKO_Dwarf) | [Warner Home Video](http://whv-amusic.com/kotoko/) | [NBC Universal Japan](http://nbcuni-music.com/kotoko/) | [YouTube ](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCYZ9uuJYYP5PX8YvpIHbEwQ)

KOTOKO is a Japanese J-pop musician, singer and songwriter. She began her singing career as a member of [I've Sound ](https://anilist.co/staff/106951/Ive) in 2000, and was later signed to Rondorobe under Geneon from 2004 to 2010. Kotoko left Geneon in 2010, left I've Sound and signed to Warner Home Video in 2011. She composes and writes lyrics (for herself as well as other singers in I've Sound) for numerous other song collections. She has contributed songs to numerous anime and video games.

[Official Website ](http://www.mami-kawada.jp/) | [Twitter ](https://twitter.com/mamikawada) | [Spotify ](https://open.spotify.com/artist/5MqHx3rECV1BvBBFG3L508?autoplay=true) 

Mami Kawada is a former Japanese pop singer and lyricist who was signed to NBCUniversal Entertainment Japan and also a member of I've Sound, a musical group which produces soundtracks for eroge (erotic games) and anime.

Kawada made her musical debut in 2001 after being discovered by her music teacher [Eiko Shimamiya](https://anilist.co/staff/100243/Eiko-Shimamiya) with the release of the song "Kaze to Kimi o Daite". She released her first single, a split-single with musician [KOTOKO](https://anilist.co/staff/100076/KOTOKO), in 2002, and her first solo single was released in 2005. Her first album, Seed, was released in 2006. She first performed overseas in Taiwan in 2007 and later appeared at the Bangkok Comic Con in Thailand in 2014.

Kawada's songs have been featured as theme music for various anime shows such as the Shakugan no Shana and A Certain Magical Index series. She has performed theme songs for various eroge such as Love, Election and Chocolate and Aokana: Four Rhythm Across the Blue. She has also written songs for other musicians. During the LisAni 2016 event, Kawada announced her retirement from singing activities following a final concert in May 2016.

[Official Website ](http://www.mami-kawada.jp/) | [Twitter ](https://twitter.com/mamikawada) | [Spotify ](https://open.spotify.com/artist/5MqHx3rECV1BvBBFG3L508?autoplay=true)

The founder and former representative director of [Funimation](https://anilist.co/studio/102/).

**Non-anime roles:**
- Policeman in "Chuck E. Cheese in the Galaxy 5000"
[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/鈴木行)

[Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/yamacane0901/) | [Blog (jp)](https://ameblo.jp/kanku0901/) | [YouTube](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCcZ_aVrm0ux7Jw2G5jgq6Gw/)

Yutaka Yamamoto is a director, scriprtwriter, lyricist and storyboarder. Infamous for his incendiary behavior on Twitter and for having been fired from [Kyoto Animation](https://anilist.co/studio/2/) and [Ordet](https://anilist.co/studio/334/), the latter of which he helped co-found. 

As a member of Kyoto Animation, he rose to prominence within the company after serving as assistant director on [Munto 2: Beyond the Walls of Time](https://anilist.co/anime/1135/). In 2006, he was selected to be the chief episode director of [The Melancholy of Haruhi Suzumiya](https://anilist.co/anime/849/), after which he became well known among anime fans for the ending dance theme he choreographed. He was to make his full directorial debut with [Lucky Star](https://anilist.co/anime/1887/), but was replaced after four episodes due to "performance issues." In a later radio interview, Yamamoto confirmed he was fired by Kyoto Animation and unsuccessfully attempted to win back his job. 

Yamamoto has threatened to quit his career in anime production six times over the years. In May 2019, Yamamoto vowed never to "work on anything related to animation again" after finishing [Hakubo](https://anilist.co/anime/98784/). He has become notorious for his incendiary behavior on Twitter, including calling fans of anime "mentally disabled," discriminatory remarks about Chinese and Korean anime fans, and attacking his former cast members, which resulted in him being temporarily suspended from Twitter in 2018.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/TkashiWatanabe)

Joined Top Craft as an animator while still attending university, switched his focus to directing in the late '80s.

Married to [Miyata Naomi](https://anilist.co/staff/220081/).

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/TkashiWatanabe)

Joined Top Craft as an animator while still attending university, switched his focus to directing in the late '80s.

Married to [Miyata Naomi](https://anilist.co/staff/220081/).
She was nicknamed "Yasuko Nyan" by her godfather Naomi Takebe, a producer at [Toei Animation](https://anilist.co/studio/18/Toei-Animation).

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/明田川仁)

Affiliated with Magic Capsule, a recording studio led by his father [Susumu Aketagawa](https://anilist.co/staff/120062).

__Kazuya Takase__ is a Japanese composer, arranger and founder of the sound unit I've Sound, which features the so-called "Love Planet Five", which is composed of 5 prolific singers in the Trance/J-pop industry (KOTOKO, Kaori Utatsuki, Eiko Shimamiya, MELL, and Mami Kawada).  Takase acts as a composer and arranger for the themes and OSTs of various anime and eroge games.

Takase acts as a composer and arranger for the themes and OSTs of various anime and eroge games.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/大塚舞)

Originating from [Shaft](https://anilist.co/studio/44/). Currently freelance.

Aspired to become an animator after having seen [Densetsu no Yuusha Da Garn](https://anilist.co/anime/2803/).

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/bakusyousuika) | [Pixiv](https://www.pixiv.net/en/users/15355517) | [Youtube](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCsdfYXxtj5nCYIyQ7ZZLkyw)

Close friends with [Atsushi Nishigori](https://anilist.co/staff/104029/) and [Akira Amemiya](https://anilist.co/staff/100956/).

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/Nakazawa0109)

Tomoyuki Nakazawa is a Japanese composer, arranger and music producer. He is a former member of the music unit I've.
